speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the seizures you're experiencing? Were they generalized, focal, or did they change in type over time?

speaker: Patient
text: They were more like a... a sudden jerk, and my body stiffened for a bit, then relaxed. I don't really know how to describe it, but it felt like my whole body just froze for a second.

speaker: Doctor
text: That sounds like a sudden, brief episode of tonic-clonic seizure activity, but it's unusual for a newborn to experience seizures that are so clearly focal, can you tell me if the episode started in your arms, legs, or somewhere else?

speaker: Patient
text: I think it started in my arms, actually. It felt like my arms stiffened up really quickly, and then my whole body just... locked up, I guess. It was really scary.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the lethargy you've been experiencing? Was it a gradual change, or did it happen suddenly?

speaker: Patient
text: It started slowly, I guess. I was awake and alert one minute, and then I just felt... a bit sleepy, and then I couldn't seem to wake up. It's like my body just... shut down, I suppose.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your sleep patterns before the lethargy started? Were you having trouble sleeping, or did you notice any other changes in your behavior or physical condition? Also, have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, vomiting, or difficulty breathing? And can you show me your arms and legs, I'd like to take a look.

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I wasn't really sleeping much before, I was just kind of... resting a lot, I guess. I was always feeling tired, even when I was awake, and I just couldn't seem to shake it off. As for other symptoms, I don't think I've had a fever, but my mom did say I've been having a bit of trouble breathing sometimes, and my skin does feel a bit warm to the touch. And, um, I don't really know how to move my arms and legs right now, they feel kind of... heavy, I suppose.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to examine your arms and legs a bit more. Can you try to move them for me, even if it feels a bit heavy? And can you show me your tongue, please? Is it hanging out of your mouth, or is it sticking back against the roof?

speaker: Patient
text: I'll try to move my arms... *pauses, then tries to lift a hand slightly* It's really hard, doc. It feels like there's something holding them down. *lowers hand back down* And my tongue... *tries to stick it back against the roof of the mouth, but it doesn't quite make it* I think it's just kind of... hanging out, I guess.

speaker: Doctor
text: I see that the seizures seem to be quite brief, but the lethargy has been persistent. Can you tell me more about the time of day when you're usually most alert and awake? Is it during the day or at night? Also, I'd like to check your reflexes. Can you flex your toes for me?

speaker: Patient
text: I usually feel more awake at night, I guess. It's like my body just... winds down a bit during the day, and then I feel more alert when it's dark. I'm not really sure why, it just feels that way. And, um, I'll try to flex my toes for you... *pauses, then slowly tries to lift the toes, but it's a slow and laborious movement*

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like your body has a natural circadian rhythm that affects your level of alertness. I'd like to examine your reflexes a bit further. Can you try to move your big toe on your left foot for me, and then your right toe? Also, I'd like to check your cranial nerves. Can you tell me if you can see or hear anything when I shine a light in your eyes or make a loud noise? REQUEST TEST: Neurological Exam

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital Signs: Blood Pressure: 60/30 mm Hg Heart Rate: 123 bpm Respiratory Rate: 50 breaths/min Neurological Examination: Consciousness Level: Lethargic Fontanelle: Tense anterior fontanelle Pupil Reactivity: Sluggish Muscle Tone: Decreased in all extremities Eye Movements: Slow, conjugate back and forth movements Reflexes: Big Toe (Left Foot): Absent Big Toe (Right Foot): Absent Cranial Nerve Exam: Visual Response: No response to light Auditory Response: No response to loud noise

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation you experience when you try to move your arms and legs? Does it feel like they're being pulled down, or is it more like they're heavy and hard to lift?

speaker: Patient
text: It feels like... my arms and legs are stuck down, like there's something holding them in place. I try to lift them, but it's like they're weighed down by an invisible force. It's really hard to explain, but it's like my muscles just can't cooperate with me.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation you experience when you try to move your arms and legs? Does it feel like they're being pulled down, or is it more like they're heavy and hard to lift? And I'd like to request some more images, please. Can you show me your face and neck, and I'd like to examine your mouth and throat for any signs of infection or other abnormalities?

speaker: Patient
text: It feels like my arms and legs are stuck down, like there's something holding them in place. I try to lift them, but it's like they're weighed down by an invisible force. It's really hard to explain, but it's like my muscles just can't cooperate with me. As for my face and neck, I don't really know how to move them, to be honest. They feel kind of... stiff and heavy too. And my mouth and throat, I don't think I can really open my mouth very wide. It's hard to breathe, and my tongue feels like it's stuck in the back of my mouth. I'll try to open my mouth for you, but it's really hard. *tries to open mouth, but it's a slow and labored movement*

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to take a closer look at your face and neck. Can you slowly turn your head to the right for me, and then to the left? Also, I'd like to examine your mouth and throat more closely. Can you try to swallow for me, and then cough? And regarding the sensation in your arms and legs, it sounds like you're experiencing some significant muscle weakness. I'd like to check your muscle strength more thoroughly. Can you try to squeeze my hand for me, and then release it? Also, I'd like to request some more images of your muscles, specifically the biceps and quadriceps. REQUEST IMAGES: Muscle Ultrasound Also, I'd like to check your skin for any signs of rash or other abnormalities. Can you show me your arms and legs again, and I'd like to examine your skin more closely?

speaker: Patient
text: I'll try to turn my head to the right... *slowly turns head to the right, then to the left* I think I'm a bit stiff, though. It's hard to move my neck. I'll try to swallow for you... *swallows slowly* It feels like my tongue is stuck in the back of my mouth, like I said before. And coughing is really hard, too. *coughs weakly* I'll try to squeeze your hand... *tries to squeeze hand, but it's a slow and weak movement* It feels like my muscles are just... not working right. I don't know how to explain it. I don't have any rashes or anything on my skin, that I can feel. But my skin does feel kind of... warm to the touch, like I said before. *tries to show arms and legs again, but they feel heavy and unresponsive*

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the sensation you experience when you try to move your tongue? Does it feel like it's stuck in your mouth, or is it more like it's just not moving properly? Also, I'd like to check your respiratory function further. Can you take a few deep breaths for me, and then try to blow air out slowly through pursed lips? And regarding your skin, you mentioned it feels warm to the touch - is that a constant sensation, or does it come and go?

speaker: Patient
text: It feels like my tongue is stuck in the back of my mouth, like I've said before. It's hard to move, and when I try, it just feels like it's going to fall out or something. And, um, the warmth, it's always there, I think. It's hard to say, but it's just a constant feeling, like my body is always a bit... off.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the warmth you're feeling in your body? Is it a constant sensation, or does it come and go? And can you try to move your tongue again for me, slowly this time, and see if you can get it to move back to the front of your mouth?

speaker: Patient
text: I'd say it's always there, like my body is just... warm all the time. I don't know, it's hard to explain. And, um, trying to move my tongue again... *tries to move tongue slowly* It feels like it's just... stuck, like I said before. It doesn't want to move, and it feels kind of... tight in the back of my mouth.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you try to speak for me, please? Can you make a sound, like "ah" or "oh", and then try to move your tongue to make a word? Please go ahead and try.

speaker: Patient
text: I... *tries to make a sound, but it's a weak, strained "m" sound*... and... *tries to move tongue to make a word, but it doesn't seem to be working right*... I don't think I can... *pauses, trying to make another sound, but it's not coming out right*

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're having a lot of trouble moving your tongue and speaking. Can you try to make a different sound, like a "b" or "d" sound, and see if you can move your tongue to make a word? Also, I'd like to check your gag reflex. Can you try to swallow a small amount of water for me, and then gag? REQUEST TEST: Swallowing Test

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital Signs: Blood Pressure: 60/30 mm Hg Heart Rate: 123 bpm Respiratory Rate: 50 breaths/min Neurological Examination: Consciousness Level: Lethargic Fontanelle: Tense anterior fontanelle Pupil Reactivity: Sluggish Muscle Tone: Decreased in all extremities Eye Movements: Slow, conjugate back and forth movements Reflexes: Big Toe (Left Foot): Absent Big Toe (Right Foot): Absent Cranial Nerve Exam: Visual Response: No response to light Auditory Response: No response to loud noise Swallowing Test: Swallowing: Successful Swallowing of water, with minimal gag response

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask a few more questions to get a better understanding of what's going on. Can you tell me more about the sensation you experience when you try to swallow? Does it feel like your tongue is moving properly, or is it like it's stuck or not working right? Also, I'd like to request some more images of your brain and spine to rule out any structural abnormalities. REQUEST TEST: MRI

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital Signs: Blood Pressure: 60/30 mm Hg Heart Rate: 123 bpm Respiratory Rate: 50 breaths/min Neurological Examination: Consciousness Level: Lethargic Fontanelle: Tense anterior fontanelle Pupil Reactivity: Sluggish Muscle Tone: Decreased in all extremities Eye Movements: Slow, conjugate back and forth movements Reflexes: Big Toe (Left Foot): Absent Big Toe (Right Foot): Absent Cranial Nerve Exam: Visual Response: No response to light Auditory Response: No response to loud noise Swallowing Test: Swallowing: Successful Swallowing of water, with minimal gag response Neurological Questions: Swallowing Sensation: Describes sensation as if tongue is "stuck" or "paralyzed" during swallowing. MRI Results: Brain Imaging: No evidence of bleeding or structural abnormalities. Spinal Imaging: No evidence of spinal cord compression or abnormalities.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like we've gathered a lot of information about your symptoms and physical examination findings. I'd like to summarize what we've discussed so far. You've been experiencing seizures, which seem to be focal and brief, but have been persistent. You've also been experiencing lethargy, which started slowly and has been ongoing. You've had trouble moving your arms and legs, and your muscles seem to be weak. Your tongue is also stuck in the back of your mouth, and you've had trouble speaking. I'd like to ask a few more questions to get a better understanding of what's going on. Can you tell me more about your breathing difficulties? Are you having trouble taking deep breaths, or do you feel like your lungs are not expanding properly? Also, I'd like to request some more images of your brain and spinal cord to rule out any structural abnormalities. REQUEST TEST: CT Scan And one more thing, can you tell me more about your mother's medical history? Has she had any previous pregnancies or deliveries that were complicated?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital Signs: Blood Pressure: 60/30 mm Hg Heart Rate: 123 bpm Respiratory Rate: 50 breaths/min Neurological Examination: Consciousness Level: Lethargic Fontanelle: Tense anterior fontanelle Pupil Reactivity: Sluggish Muscle Tone: Decreased in all extremities Eye Movements: Slow, conjugate back and forth movements Reflexes: Big Toe (Left Foot): Absent Big Toe (Right Foot): Absent Cranial Nerve Exam: Visual Response: No response to light Auditory Response: No response to loud noise Swallowing Test: Swallowing: Successful Swallowing of water, with minimal gag response Neurological Questions: Swallowing Sensation: Describes sensation as if tongue is "stuck" or "paralyzed" during swallowing. CT Scan Results: Brain Imaging: No evidence of bleeding or structural abnormalities. Spinal Imaging: No evidence of spinal cord compression or abnormalities. Medical History: Mother's Medical History: No previous complications during pregnancies or deliveries.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to ask a few more questions about your breathing difficulties. Can you tell me more about the sensation you experience when you try to breathe in deeply? Does it feel like your lungs are expanding properly, or is it like they're not filling up with air? Also, I'd like to check your oxygen saturation levels. Can you try to take a few deep breaths for me, and I'll use an oxygen saturation monitor to see how well your lungs are getting oxygen? And one more thing, I'd like to review the test results again. The CT scan and MRI results don't show any structural abnormalities, but the neurological examination findings suggest that there may be an issue with your brain or spinal cord function. I'd like to ask a few more questions to try to narrow down the possible causes. Can you tell me more about the sensation you experience when you try to move your arms and legs? Does it feel like they're being pulled down, or is it like they're just not moving properly?

speaker: Patient
text: It feels like... my arms and legs just aren't working right. They feel heavy and unresponsive, like they're stuck in place. When I try to move them, it's like they're being pulled down or weighted down by something invisible.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like you're having a lot of trouble with your motor function and sensation. I'd like to ask a few more questions to try to narrow down the possible causes. Can you tell me more about the sensation you experience when you try to swallow? Does it feel like your tongue is moving properly, or is it like it's stuck or not working right? And one more thing, I'd like to review the test results again. The CT scan and MRI results don't show any structural abnormalities, but the neurological examination findings suggest that there may be an issue with your brain or spinal cord function. I'd like to ask a few more questions to try to get a better understanding of what's going on. Can you tell me more about your mother's feeding habits during breastfeeding? Has she been having trouble latching or has the baby had trouble latching? (This is question 19 of 20.)

speaker: Patient
text: I... *pauses, trying to think of how to answer*... my mom has been trying to breastfeed me, but I don't think it's going very well. I try to latch on, but it feels like my mouth is just... stuck, and I can't get the milk in. Sometimes it feels like my tongue is just... hanging out, and I have to use my chin to get the milk in. *looks down, trying to hide the struggle*

speaker: Doctor
text: I think I understand what's going on. It sounds like you're having a lot of trouble with your sucking and swallowing abilities, and it's affecting your feeding and overall development. Can you tell me more about the sensation you experience when you try to suck on a pacifier or a bottle? Does it feel like your tongue is moving properly, or is it like it's stuck or not working right? Also, I'd like to request some more images of your oral cavity to take a closer look at your tongue and mouth. REQUEST IMAGES: Lateral X-Ray of Oral Cavity

speaker: Patient
text: I... *tries to suck on a pacifier, but it feels like my tongue is just hanging out and can't move properly*... I don't think I can get a good seal, it's like my mouth just isn't working right. *looks down, feeling frustrated and helpless*

speaker: Doctor
text: I think I understand what's going on. It sounds like you're having a lot of trouble with your sucking and swallowing abilities, and it's affecting your feeding and overall development. Based on your symptoms and the test results, I'm going to take a guess that you might have a condition called congenital hypothyroidism. This condition is caused by a lack of thyroid hormone production in the body, which can affect the development of the nervous system and other organs. It's a common cause of developmental delays and feeding difficulties in newborns. I'd like to request some more images of your thyroid gland to confirm this diagnosis. Can you please request a thyroid ultrasound? Also, I'd like to discuss treatment options with your mother. We'll need to start your on thyroid hormone replacement therapy to help stimulate the production of thyroid hormones in your body. This will help improve your feeding and overall development. Is that something you think you'd be comfortable with?

speaker: Patient
text: I don't really know what that is, doc. I just know I feel really tired and my body feels... stuck. Can you please just help me get better? I want to be able to move my arms and legs and breathe easily again.
